titleStmt.title: Ariadne deserted by Theseus Sittinge uppon a Rock in the Island Naxos thus Complaines
Theseus, O Theseus, hark! but yet in vain

head.l: Hen: Lawes / Ariadne deserted by Theseus
Sittinge uppon a Rock in yethe Island Naxos thus Complaines

lg.l: Theseous! ô theseus! heark! but yet in vaine,
alas forsaken I Complaine;
it was some Neighb'ringe Rock / more softe then he, /
whose hollow Bowels pittyed me,
& beatinge back ytthat false & cruell Name,
did Comfort & revenge my flame;
then faithles whither wilt thou flye,
stones dare not harbour Cruelty. /
Tell me yee Gods whoe Ere yee are,
why, o why, made yee him soe faire;
& tell me wretch why thou,

madst not thy
selfe more true, /
beautye from him might Coppies take,
& more majestick Heroes make,
& falshood learne a wyle,
from him too, to beguile!
restore my Clue,
tis heer most due,
for tis a labrinth of more subtle Art,
to haue soe faire a face soe fowle a hart. /
the Rav’nous Vulture teare his breast,
yethe Rowlinge stone disturbe his rest,
let him next feele
Ixions wheele,
& Ad one fable more
to Cursing Poets store,

& then -- yet rather let him liue, &
Twyne
his woofe of dayes wthwith some thred stolne from Myne.
but if you’le Torture him how Ere,
Torture my hart, you’le finde him there;
till myne Eyes dranke vp his,
& his dranke myne,
I ne’re thought souls might kiss,
& spirrits Joine
Pictures till then,
tooke mee as Much as Men,
Nature & Art,
Movinge a like my hart;
but his faire visage made me finde,
pleasures & feares
hopessighes, sigheshopes, & tearesfears,
as severall seasons of the Mynde;
Should thyne Eye Venus, on his dwell
thou wouldst Invite him to thy shell,
& caught by that liue Jett
ventur the Second net,
& after all thy dangers, faythles hee,
shouldst thou but slumber would forsake Eu’n thee;
the streames soe Court yethe yieldinge bancks,
And glydinge thence Nere pay their thankes,
the wynds soe wooe the flowres
whispringe a monge fresh bowrs;
& hauinge Robd them of their smels,
fly thence perfum’d to Other Cels;
this is familliar hate to Smyle & kill,

though
nothinge please thee yet my Ruine will;
death! houer, houer Ore me then
waues let yoryour Christall wombe,
be both my fate & Tombe;
I’le sooner trust the Sea then men. /
Yet for revenge to heau'n Ile call,
& breath One Curs before I fall;
proud of two Conquests Minautor & mee,
that by my faith, this by thy perjurye;
maiest thou forget to wing thy ships wthwith whyte,
ytthat the blacke Sailes may to yethe longinge Sight

of thy graye father tell thy fate, &
he
bequeath that sea his name falling like me,
Nature & loue thus brand thee, whylst I dye
cause thou forsakst Eugevs cause thou drawst Nighe /
And yee, O nimphs below whoe Sitt,
in whose Swift floods his vowes he writt,
Snatch A Sharp diamond from yoryour Richer Mynes,
& in Some Mirror graue these Sader lynes,
whchwhich let som God convey
to him, ytthat soe he may,
in ytthat both reade at Once & see,

those lookes ytthat
caus’d my destinye. /
In Thetis Armes, I Ariadne sleep,
drownd first in myne Owne tears, then in the deep /
twice Banished, first by loue, & then by hate,
the life ytthat I preseru’d became my fate,
whoe leauinge all was by him left a lone,
ytthat from A Monster freed, him selfe proou'ed One. /
Thus then I f— but look
